title: Choose Correct Algorithm: Majority Element
prompt: You are given an array where a majority element (appearing more than n/2 times) is guaranteed to exist. Which algorithm is best suited in O(n) time and O(1) space?

options.text: Sort the array and pick the middle element
Use a hash map to count frequencies
Use binary search on all possible values

options.text: List with both positive and negative numbers

prompt: In Python, given `x = 0`, which expression will NOT raise a `ZeroDivisionError`?

title: One-Expression Solution: Clamp Value
prompt: Best **single-expression** implementation of clamp (limit value between min_val and max_val):

options.text: return min_val if value < min_val else max_val if value > max_val else value
return value if min_val <= value <= max_val else min_val + max_val

title: Compare Implementations: Membership Testing
prompt: Which statement best describes these two membership check approaches for 10,000+ lookups on a collection of 1 million items?

options.text: list version will almost always be faster
set version is dramatically faster for lookups
list version uses much less memory

title: One-Expression Solution: Shallow Flatten
prompt: Best single-expression way to shallow flatten a list of lists?

options.text: [item for sublist in lst for item in sublist]
lst[::] if not any(isinstance(x, list) for x in lst) else lst

title: Predict Output: String Immutability Effect
prompt: What is the final value of variable s after these conceptual operations: start with s = "hello", then try to do s[0] = "H", then print s?

title: Identify Bug: Default Argument Pitfall
prompt: A function has a default parameter that is a mutable object (like a list or dict). What is the most common dangerous consequence of this design?

options.text: Changes made to the default object persist between different calls
The function can only be called once
It automatically becomes a generator function

title: Fix One Line: Range Off-by-One Concept
prompt: A loop is meant to process numbers from 1 to n inclusive, but currently processes only up to n-1. What is the typical one-line fix in Python?

options.text: Change range(1, n) to range(1, n+1)
Change range(1, n) to range(0, n)
Change range(1, n) to range(1, n-1)

title: Choose Breaking Input: List Index Error Concept
prompt: Which situation is most likely to cause an IndexError when accessing a list in Python?

options.text: Accessing index 0 in an empty list
Accessing index -1 in a list with one element
Trying to access index 5 in a list of length 100

title: Break Opponent Solution: Shallow Copy Assumption
prompt: Someone claims that using the assignment operator (=) creates a completely independent copy of a list of lists. Which operation would clearly prove them wrong?

options.text: Modifying a number inside a nested list affects both original and 'copy'
Appending to the top-level list affects both
Changing the order of the outer list affects both

title: Compare Implementations: Membership Testing Performance
prompt: For very frequent membership checks ("is this value in the collection?") on a large collection, which data structure usually gives dramatically better performance?

title: Micro-Refactor: Benefit of Early Return
prompt: What is the primary advantage of using early return (guard clauses) instead of deep nesting in a function?

options.text: It reduces indentation/nesting and improves readability
It automatically makes the function recursive

title: One-Expression Solution: Clamp Concept
prompt: What is the cleanest single-expression way in Python to clamp a value between a minimum and maximum (inclusive)?

options.text: value if min_val <= value <= max_val else min_val

title: Constraint-Imposed Fix: In-Place List Reversal
prompt: You need to reverse a list in-place using O(1) extra space and without using slicing or built-in reverse(). What is the standard algorithmic approach?

options.text: Use two pointers starting from both ends and swap until they meet
Create a new list and copy elements backward
Sort the list in reverse order

title: Sudden-Death MCQ: Truthy/Falsy Values
prompt: Which of these Python values is considered falsy in a boolean context?

title: Identify Bottleneck: List vs Set Construction
prompt: When creating a collection of unique items from a very large sequence (millions of elements), which operation is usually the performance bottleneck?

options.text: Building a set from the sequence (set(sequence))

title: Choose Correct Algorithm: Two Pointers Use Case
prompt: Which problem is classically and efficiently solved using the two-pointers technique?

options.text: Finding if a sorted array contains two numbers that sum to target
Finding the longest common prefix of strings

title: Predict Output: Boolean Ops
prompt: Given Python semantics, what is the result of evaluating the expression `True and not False`?

title: Identify Bug: Infinite Loop
prompt: A while-loop is supposed to terminate after processing each element of a list once, but it never stops. Which is the most likely bug?

options.text: The loop condition never gets updated inside the loop

title: Fix One Line: Index Error
prompt: A loop is iterating over indices of a list and sometimes raises an IndexError on the last iteration. Which fix is most likely correct?

options.text: Change the loop to iterate until and including the list length
Change the loop to iterate strictly less than the list length
Increase the list length by one before the loop
Decrease the list length by one before the loop

title: Fill Missing Line: Counter Init
prompt: A function counts how many items in a list satisfy a condition, but the result is always incorrect. The only missing line is the initialization of the counter variable. Which initialization is most appropriate?

options.text: Set the counter to 0 before the loop
Set the counter to 1 before the loop
Initialize the counter with the list length

title: Choose Correct Algorithm: Merge Sorted Lists
prompt: You must merge two already sorted lists of size n and m into one sorted list. Which algorithm is most appropriate to achieve O(n + m) time?

options.text: Insert all elements into a binary search tree
Concatenate the lists and sort the result
Use two pointers, advancing the smaller current element each time
Use linear search for each element

title: Choose Correct Complexity: Hash Set Lookup
prompt: What is the average-case time complexity of checking membership of an element in a well-implemented hash set?

title: Choose Breaking Input: All Positive Assumption
prompt: A function computes the minimum value in a list by starting from 0 and updating the minimum whenever a smaller value is found. For which kind of input list does this strategy fail?

options.text: Lists containing both positive and negative numbers

title: Identify Edge Case: Empty String
prompt: You are implementing a function that returns the first character of a string. Which edge case is essential to handle to avoid an error?

title: Does This Pass? Array Boundaries
prompt: A loop processes all elements of an array using indices from 0 up to and including the array length. Will this always avoid out-of-bounds errors?

options.text: Yes, because indices start at 0 and end at the length
No, because the last valid index is one less than the length

title: Which Line Is Wrong? OR vs AND
prompt: A compound condition is meant to check that a value is within a closed interval [L, R]. The developer wrote a condition using OR instead of AND. What is the effect of using OR?

options.text: No effect; OR and AND are equivalent here
Values outside the interval are incorrectly accepted

title: Fix Off-by-One: Inclusive Loop
prompt: You need a loop that processes all integers from 1 to n inclusive. Which loop bound description is most appropriate?

options.text: Start at 0 and stop before n
Start at 1 and stop before n
Start at 1 and stop after reaching n
Start at 0 and stop after reaching n

title: Patch Edge Case: Null Input
prompt: A function assumes its input list is never null and directly accesses its length. To safely handle a null input parameter, which behavior is generally most reasonable?

options.text: Return a neutral value such as 0 or an empty list
Silently ignore the error and continue

title: Compare Implementations: Time vs Space
prompt: One implementation removes duplicates from a list by scanning it and storing seen elements in a set. Another implementation uses a nested loop and no extra data structures. Which is generally true?

options.text: The set-based version uses more memory but is faster on large inputs
The nested-loop version uses more memory and is faster
Both have the same time and space complexity
The set-based version always has worse time complexity

title: Identify Bottleneck: Sorting Step
prompt: A program reads a list from input, sorts it, and then prints each element once. For large inputs, which step is the primary performance bottleneck?

title: Break Opponent Solution: All Zeroes
prompt: An opponent claims their function correctly detects if a list contains a positive number, but it initializes the answer to true and sets it to false only when it sees a negative number. Which type of input will break the claim?

options.text: A list with at least one positive and one negative number
A list with only positive numbers
A list with only negative numbers

title: Micro-Refactor: Early Return on Empty
prompt: A function processes a collection and runs several expensive steps even when the collection is empty. What small refactor most directly avoids the unnecessary work?

options.text: Move expensive steps into a separate function
Add an early return when the collection is empty
Rename the function to indicate it may be slow
Increase the time limit of the program

title: One-Expression Solution: Max of Three
prompt: You need a single expression that computes the maximum of three numbers a, b, and c. Which description best fits a typical implementation in a language with a built-in max function?

options.text: Take the average of the three
Use max on a and b, then max on the result and c
Sort the three numbers and take the first

title: Constraint-Imposed Fix: O(1) Extra Space
prompt: You must modify an algorithm so that it uses only constant extra space. Which type of change best satisfies this constraint?

options.text: Replace an auxiliary array with in-place updates on the original array
Add more temporary arrays but reuse some of them
Use recursion with deep call stacks
Store all intermediate results in a list

title: Language Switch Snippet: Loop Semantics
prompt: You are converting a simple "for each element in list" loop from Python to a C-like language. Which construct most closely matches the semantics?

options.text: A while-loop that manually updates an index variable
A for-loop that updates an index from 0 to length-1 and accesses elements by index
A do-while loop that always executes at least once
A switch statement on the list length

title: Sudden-Death MCQ: Short-Circuiting
prompt: In a short-circuiting logical AND expression A AND B, when is expression B evaluated?
